data.text: Carrying a Spare Folding Tire for Emergencies During a Bicycle Tour
Curious for your opinion. I want to carry a light folding tire for emergencies just in case my marathons for some crazy reason fail me while I am out east. Any recommendations? Thanks!
Is this a trick question? A folding marathon :D
data.author: Sean Quinn

data.text: nope. The trick is finding one. Been looking for months!
data.author: McKenley Newman

data.text: Have you tried their website directly? I've ordered from them before and have always had good luck. Granted, I'm in the US, so availability is probably different.
data.author: Sean Quinn

data.text: You can get Shwalbe folding tyres. And many other brands.
data.author: Simon Bebe

data.text: been looking for them for awhile sádly. Seems everyone else agrees with you and has bought them all!
data.author: McKenley Newman

data.text: I just carry an extra set of tubes. Extra tires on tour aren't really necessary
data.author: Jake Klamerus

data.text: IMHO, any folding tire would be better than none if I'm worried about a tire blowout or rupture. Good luck and enjoy your trip.
data.author: Jeff Koski

data.text: agreed completely.
data.author: McKenley Newman

data.text: I wouldn’t worry about it. Especially with marathons.
data.author: Mick Swanson

data.text: Tyre size? I ride 650b c47 so pretty chonky boys but they fold up really neat i ride WTB venture
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: We carry a 700 x 28c folding tyre on long trips. Its got us out of trouble twice. Got it from Decathlon.
data.author: Michael Richards

data.text: interesting. Super light i guess. Hmmm
data.author: McKenley Newman

data.text: 360g
data.author: Michael Richards

data.text: No need spare tyre, you can have patches for tyre in case of big cut but marathons are really good, same I did 10.000km in South America before changing mine. Keep this extra weight for food :)
data.author: Adrien Gss

data.text: Schwalbe marathon mondial foldable
data.author: Stéphane Sintès

data.text: Schwalbe Marathon Mondial are great touring tires. Rather than an emergency backup, consider it a proper spare.
data.author: Tristan Natsirt

data.text: been looking for these for roughly three months but no one has them it seems. Especially the farther east i have gotten.
data.author: McKenley Newman

data.text:
I'm not sure what continent you're on, but I always order from Bike24. Reasonable international shipping and good prices. If you know where you'll be in a month or so, maybe you can order ahead to a Warmshowers host's house or something. Just check about customs and import stuff for whatever country you're going to be in. https://www.bike24.de/suche?searchTerm=mondial
Bike24 - Suche
bike24.de
data.author: Tristan Natsirt

data.text: Don't listen to the people telling you not to take a spare tyre.
data.author: Pdl Breaking

data.text: Extra tires aren’t necessary. I’ve had two fail and both times a shim kept it together until I could get to an LBS. I also push my tires to the end. My current ones have over 8K miles on them and will need changed at the end of this tour. The chances of a catastrophic failure is rare.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: we just dealt with one here in turkey which got me thinking more about a spare as i head east is all. Shim was my original plan but after dealing with this last issue on a friends bike i started considering otherwise.
data.author: McKenley Newman

data.text: Carried one foldable for a couple years, never needed it.
data.author: Clyde Slade

data.text: A back up folding tire is a smart item in my opinion.
data.author: Joe Trudo

data.text: My back-up tyre is a roll of gaffa tape.
data.author: Ray Carty

data.text: already in the bag. Totally agree.
data.author: McKenley Newman

data.text: Someone mentioned gaffer tape/Duck tape, this can actually work. There are also tire boots. In the extrememly unlikely evet that you slice a tire or rupture the tire wall. For ruptures, tire boots sit in the tire over the hole, you then put in your tube and inflate. The tire boot stops the tube from expanding out of the tire wall. You can also use a dollar bill, as it is a non paper material and is waterproof. With a major slice you can wind a cloth tape, like gaffer tape, around both the wheel rim and the tire, going between the spokes. This will bind everything together. Yes you will be riding on tape for part of the wheel rotation but it will get you down the road. A good reason to carry a spare tire is if you are running an odd size diameter of tire, that most shops will not stock and might need a special order (delivery times may hurt your schedule).
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: I have some side wall repair supplies with me but not seen the boot which is pretty cool! Thanks for showing me that. But yea it more that where i am at it will be hard to find any tires so it's nicer to have one. All good suggestions.
data.author: McKenley Newman

data.text: As an extra note. The tires with the light brown walls are more likely to get wall damage. The wall is not as tough.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Really? Just with certain brands or with all?
data.author: McKenley Newman

data.text:
It takes a lot of abuse to damage a Schwalbe Marathon tyre, but I have seen it done, a ham fisted amateur using brute force and tyre levers, no doubt. I never carry a spare tyre when touring on them but if you want to carry a spare https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y6i1Con0gPE
How To Fold A Spare Bike Tire For Bicycle Touring
youtube.com
data.author: Richard Cooley

data.text: that is brutal. Never seen this before haha. Wonderful tip.
data.author: McKenley Newman

data.text:
On some of my remote tours I’ve carried a spare vase well and, like you, didn’t want too much weight. Expensive but the ReneHerse tires are quite light. https://www.renehersecycles.com/product-category/components/tires/
Tires – Rene Herse Cycles
renehersecycles.com
data.author: Scott Diamond

data.text: sweet i will check these out! Thank you.
data.author: McKenley Newman
